si.title: ශ්රී ලංකා නීති විද්යාලය Imalling ාතනය කිරීම
body_lines: 1874 දී ශ්රී ලංකා නීති විද්යාලයේ පැරණිතම ආසියාවේ පැරණිතම වෘත්තීය ආයතනය විසින් ආරම්භ කරන ලදී. අද වන විට එය ආයතනයක් බවට පත්ව ඇත. සංවත්සරය සැමරීම කර ඇත, "ශ්රී ලංකාවේ නීති අධ්යාපනය නංවාලීම: අවුරුදු 150 නීති විද්යාලය."වසර හයක් තුළ වසර තුනක් අමාරු පර්යේෂණ තුනක්, අවුරුදු තුනක් නොමැති නම් දෙක විය හැකි දේ සම්පීඩනය කිරීම, ඔක්තෝබර් 18 වන දින එළිදැක්වීමේදී මෙම පොත 18 වන දින එළිදැක්වීමේදී දුටුවේය - එනම්, පසුගිය සිකුරාදා.
The book tries to make its contribution to our society, its continuing relevance, clearer. එය මෙය කරන්නේ එහි te තිහාසික පරිණාමය බහු දෘෂ්ටි කෝණයන්ගෙන් ගවේෂණය කිරීමෙනි.
එය බොහෝ ප්රශ්න මතු කරයි. සමහර විට ඒවායින් වඩාත්ම වැදගත් දෙය නම් මෙයයි: ආයතන තමන් වාසය කරන සමාජවලට අදාළ වන ආකාරය, ඔවුන් සේවය කරන ජනතාවගේ තවත් නියෝජිතයෙකු වන්නේ කෙසේද?
එම ප්රශ්නයට පිළිතුරු සැපයීම සඳහා, නියමිත වේලාවට ආපසු යා යුතුය.

ශ්රී ලංකාවේ නීති පද්ධතිය යටත් විජිත හමුවීමකට පෙරද?. ගල් හා පාෂාණ සෙල්ල් ඇතුළු historical තිහාසික වාර්තා, අපේ රජවරු සහ පාලකයෝ අධිකරණ ස්වාධීනත්වය පිළිබඳ අදහසට ගරු කළ ආකාරය ගැන අපට පවසති. නීතිය හා සාමය, යුක්තිය සහ සමානාත්මතාවය පිළිබඳ සමකාලීනයන් හා සමානාත්මතාවය යෙදීම සඳහා ආකාන්ත්රවාදී වුවත්, අපගේ අතීතයට, මෙම පරමාදර්ශයන්ට යුරෝපීය යටත් විජිතවාදයට පෙර ශක්තිමත් වූ බව පෙන්වීමට ප්රමාණවත් සාක්ෂි තිබේ.

කෙසේ වෙතත්, නීති අධ්යාපනය පිළිබඳ සමකාලීන පරමාදර්ශය යටත් විජිත උරුමයකි. අපේ පළමු යුරෝපීය යටත් විජිතවාදීන් වන පෘතුගීසීන් එහි යටත් වැසියන් ඔවුන් සමඟ ගෙන ආ නීති මත පවා එහි යටත් වැසියන්ට කරදර කළේ නැත. ඔවුන්ගේ අනුප්රාප්තිකයන් වන ලන්දේසීන් වඩාත් සූක්ෂ්ම an ෝෂා වූ අතර රටේ සිරිතේ හා දේශීය නීති කේතනය කිරීමේ තරමකට යති.

The historian and archivist Nadeera Rupesinghe contends in her book on Dutch lawmaking in Sri Lanka that the Dutch bequeathed to the country a highly pluralist legal system, one that has not been matched since. ඔවුන් නීති අධ්යාපන ක්රමයක් සකස් නොකළේ නම්, ඔවුන් පසුකාලීනව දශක කිහිපය තුළ එවැනි පද්ධතියක් සෑදීමට උපකාර කළ හැකි නීතිමය සම්ප්රදායක් අතහැර ගියහ.

පෘතුගීසීන් හෝ ලන්දේසියට වඩා බ්රිතාන්ය, සිවිල් සේවයේ පුරෝගාමීන්, සිවිල් සේවයේ පුරෝගාමීන් සහ පෘතුගීසීන් හෝ ලන්දේසියට වඩා වැඩි වශයෙන් යටත් විජිත ව්යාපෘතියේ පුරෝගාමීන් මෙම කාරණය පිළිබඳව වෙනස් මතයක් දැරීය. They continued with efforts at codifying customary laws, prominently Kandyan law, but they were driven by a fanatical zeal to ensure deference to their institutions, including their laws and customs.

19 වන සියවසේ යුරෝපීය සිරිත් විරිත්, පුරුදු, පුරුදු සහ අගතියට කැපවූ ප්රභූන්ගේ පටු කවයක් පෝෂණය කිරීම, ශ්රී ලංකාවේ හෝ ලංකාවේ හැරීමක් හමු විය. ශ්රී ලංකාවේ බ්රිතාන්ය නිලධාරීන් ඉඳහිට ඔවුන්ගේ පාලනයට එරෙහිව ඉඳහිට කැරැල්ල නොතකා ඔවුන්ට යටත් වීමට තරමක් කැමැත්තෙන් සිටියහ. 1948 දී නිදහස ලබා ගන්නා කාලය වන විට රට ආසියාවේ වඩාත්ම ගතානුගතික ජනපදයක් ලෙස කීර්තියක් ලබා තිබුණි.

යමෙකු නීති විද්යාලයේ ඉතිහාසය සහ ගමන් පථය සටහන් කළ යුතු බව මෙම පසුබිමට එරෙහිව ය. 1874 දී, නෛතික අධ්යාපන කවුන්සිලය ආරම්භ කරන ලද විට, සමෘද්ධිමත් මධ්යම පංතියක්, ප්රතිසංස්කරණවාදියෙකු ඔවුන්ගේ දෘෂ්ටියට රැඩිකල් නොවේ නම්, රට තුළ බිහි වී තිබේ.

අසංඛ්යාත විද්වතුන්, කැපී පෙනෙන ලෙස කුමාරි ජයවර්ධන මහතා සඳහන් කර ඇති අතර, මෙම මධ්යම පංතියේ මේ මධ්යම පා පන්තිය විවිධ අංශවලට වඩා ගතානුගතික හා ජාතිකවාදීන් වූ අතර තවත් සමහරු යටත් විජිත පරිපාලනය සමඟ සහයෝගයෙන් කටයුතු කිරීමට කැමැත්තක් දැක්වූ අතර තවත් සමහරු ප්රතිසංස්කරණ කටයුතු සඳහා යනාදියෝ වෙති. Almost all of them were content with their country falling within the orbit of British imperialism.

ඕනෑම දෙයකට වඩා, මෙම මධ්යම පංතිය ඔවුන්ගේ ස්ථාවරය සහ කීර්තිය පවත්වා ගැනීමේ මාර්ග සොයා බැලීය. In the last quarter of the 19th century, the professions held a certain appeal for them. විශේෂයෙන් වෛද්ය විද්යාව හා නීතියක් මගින් තත්වය නොමැති නම් ධනවත්කමට පොරොන්දු වූ බවක් පෙනෙන්නට තිබුණි. As the sociologist Ralph Pieris would much later write:

“In Ceylon, specialisation was limited by the narrow range of career opportunities of an elitist kind, the lowest in terms of status being that of graduate teacher, the highest the prestigious Civil Service.”

උපාධිධාරී ගුරුවරයා සහ සිවිල් සේවය අතර, ලංකාව ඔවුන්ගේ ජීවිතයේ දුම්රිය ස්ථානය අනුව තෝරා ගැනීමට බොහෝ දේ තිබුණි. කෙසේ වෙතත්, මධ්යම පංතියේ, කෙසේ වෙතත්, විරුද්ධාභාසයකට මුහුණ දුන්නේය: යටත් විජිත ප්රභූව ධනයේ වාසි ඔවුන්ට නොතිබූ නමුත් දෙවැන්න සමාන අභිලාෂයන් අනුව සජීවිකරණය විය. In the late 19th century, only medicine, and to a greater degree law, could square the circle and resolve this dilemma.

20 වන සියවස තුළ නීති Lawyers යින් බලගතු කණ්ඩායමක් පිහිටුවා ගත්හ. The Council of Legal Education, the sole body responsible for the admission and regulation of lawyers – Advocates and Proctors then, Attorneys-at-Law now – produced some of the most reformist, and also some of the most conservative, faces of colonial society.

නිදහස සඳහා අරගලයේ සන්දර්භය තුළ ඔවුන්ගේ මැදිහත්වීම නොසලකා හැරිය නොහැකිය. බ්රිතාන්ය අධිරාජ්යයෙන් පූර්ණ නිදහස ලබා ගැනීමට පළමු දේශපාලන පක්ෂය, ලංකා සම සමාජ පක්ෂය 1935 දී පිහිටුවන ලද අතර එය සිය පළමු කණ්ඩායම අතරට, කථා කිරීමට, වෛද්යවරයකු සහ නීති lawyer යෙකු. A. වික්රමසිංහ, සහ කොල්වින් ආර්. ද සිල්වා.

තවත් උදාහරණයක් දීමට, 1911 ව්යවස්ථාදායක සභා මැතිවරණයෙන් සාකච්ඡා කර ඇති අතර, මෙම වෘත්තියෙන් නියෝජිතයන් දෙදෙනෙකු මත උගත් බොහෝ කතාබහට ලක්ව ඇත: සිංහල ගෝමිගම එලයිට්ගේ ප්රියතම පොන්නම්බලම් රාමනාදන් සහ ආචාර්ය මාකස් ප්රනාන්දු සහ ආචාර්ය මාකස් ප්රනාන්දු සහ ආචාර්ය මාකස් ප්රනාන්දු සහ ආචාර්ය මාකස් ප්රනාන්දු සහ ආචාර්ය මාකස් ප්රනාන්දු සහ ආචාර්ය මාකස් ප්රනාන්දු සහ ආචාර්ය මාකස් ප්රනාන්දු සහ ආචාර්ය මාකස් ප්රනාන්දුකරවා ධනේශ්වරය.

අද, ඇත්ත වශයෙන්ම, දේවල් නාටකාකාර ලෙස වෙනස් වී ඇත. Right after or before independence, Sri Lanka’s first Cabinet Minister for Education, Eddie Nugawela, made some remarks about the social composition among students at his school, Royal College.

කන්නෙරාරාගේ යෝජනා නිසා නුගවේලා කියා සිටියේ, "රාජකීය විද්යාලය ධනවත් හා වරප්රසාදිත පංති සඳහා පාසලක් නොවේ."519 න් 317 ක් "පෙම්වතා, කම්කරුවන්, චපර්වරුන්, චපර්වරුන්, චපර්වරුන්, චැෆර්වරුන් සහ යල්පැන" ලෙස කටයුතු කළ බව නිරීක්ෂණය කළ ඔහු නිගමනය කළේ පාසල සිය දොරටු "පහළ මධ්යම පංතිය" සඳහා විවෘත කර ඇති බවයි.

It is transformations like these that have made institutions in Sri Lanka more representative, inclusive, and relevant, than they were at the heyday of colonialism. අද වන අභියෝගය වන්නේ මෙම ආයතන හැකි තරම් ප්රජාවන් සඳහා මෙම ආයතන විවෘත කරන අතරම ප්රමිති, ආචාර ධර්ම සහ මිණුම් සලකුණු පවත්වා ගැනීමයි.
This is not something we can stop; it is something we must accept.
මෙම පොත, ඔහුගේම නිහතමානීව, මෙම ප්රශ්න හා ගැටළු සමඟ පොළඹවා ගැනීමට උත්සාහ කරයි. It is not meant as a final word on the subject, but rather an attempt that must be followed by many other attempts.

සත්යය නම් ශ්රී ලංකා නීති විද්යාලය කාලය පිළිබඳ පරීක්ෂණයට ඔරොත්තු දුන් ආයතනයක් බවයි. It is currently going through a major bout of reform. One can only hope that as it forges ahead, it remains mindful of its essential task – ensuring a legal profession that is closer to, representative of, inclusive of, and accountable to its people.
අපි අපේ දේශපාලන politicians යින් සහ තේරී පත් වූ නිලධාරීන්ගෙන් වගවීම ඉල්ලා සිටිමු. As the author of the book, I cannot imagine why we should not do the same with our professions and professionals.

Institutions have a large role to play in this. බොහෝ විට, ශ්රී ලංකාවේ ආයතන භෞමික වීමට නැඹුරු, සමහර විට අකාරුණිකව. ඔවුන් සහයෝගීතාව හා සහයෝගීතාවයට අකමැති, ඔවුන් තමන්ටම ගෞරවය ප්රකාශ කිරීමට නැඹුරු වෙති. Sri Lanka is currently at a crossroads in its modern history. එය දියුණුව කිරීම නම්, එය මෙම ආකල්පය අතහැර දැමිය යුතුය.
අවසානයේදී, මෙම පොතේ පදිංචිව සිටින්නේ, සහ, එහි විශේෂ ආකාරයකින්, ශ්රී ලංකා නීති විද්යාලයේ අනාගතයයි.

UDIA විසින් "ශ්රී ලංකාවේ නෛතික අධ්යාපනය නේදනය කිරීමේ නෛතික විද්යාලය" හි කතුවරයා වන අතර එය ඔක්තෝබර් 18 වන දින දියත් කරන ලදී.. මෙම පොත නීති විද්යාලයෙන් ලබා ගත හැකිය. Research and compilation for the book was done by Factum, an Asia-Pacific focused foreign policy think-tank where Uditha currently serves as Chief International Relations Analyst. Email: udakdev1@gmail.com
Leave a Reply Cancel replyYour email address will not be published. Required fields are marked *Comment * Name *
ඊළඟ වතාවේ මම මේ බ්රව්සරයේ මගේ නම, විද්යුත් තැපෑල සහ වෙබ් අඩවිය සුරකින්න.

ta.title: இலங்கை சட்டக் கல்லூரியை வரலாற்றுச் செய்தல்
body_lines: The Sri Lanka Law College, reputedly Asia’s oldest professional institution, was established 150 years ago, in 1874. Today, it has become an institution unto itself.To commemorate the anniversary, the institution came out with a publication: “Uplifting Legal Education in Sri Lanka: 150 Years of Law College.” Compressing what could have been two, if not three, years of hard research into six months, the book saw the light of day at a launch on October 18 – that is, last Friday.
The book tries to make its contribution to our society, its continuing relevance, clearer. அதன் வரலாற்று பரிணாமத்தை பல கண்ணோட்டங்களிலிருந்து ஆராய்வதன் மூலம் இதைச் செய்கிறது.

It also raises many questions. Perhaps the most important of them is this: how do institutions become relevant to the societies they inhabit, how do they become more representative of the people they serve?
To answer that question, it is necessary to go back in time.

Sri Lanka’s legal system predates the colonial encounter. Historical records, including stone and rock inscriptions, tell us of how our kings and rulers respected the idea of judicial autonomy. Even though it may be anachronistic to apply contemporary notions of law and order, justice and equity, to our past, there is enough evidence to show that these ideals were respected, even reinforced, prior to European colonialism.

The contemporary ideal of legal education, however, is very much a colonial inheritance. எங்கள் முதல் ஐரோப்பிய குடியேற்றவாசிகள், போர்த்துகீசியர்கள், அதன் பாடங்களுக்கு கல்வி கற்பிப்பதில் கவலைப்படவில்லை, அவர்கள் அவர்களுடன் கொண்டு வந்த சட்டங்கள் கூட. Their successors, the Dutch, were more nuanced, going to the extent of codifying customary and indigenous laws in the country.

The historian and archivist Nadeera Rupesinghe contends in her book on Dutch lawmaking in Sri Lanka that the Dutch bequeathed to the country a highly pluralist legal system, one that has not been matched since. If they did not set up a legal education system, they left behind a legal tradition that could help form such a system in later decades.

பிரிட்டிஷ், சிவில் சர்வீஸ் மற்றும் காலனித்துவ திட்டத்தின் முன்னோடிகள் போர்த்துகீசியம் அல்லது டச்சுக்காரர்களை விட, இந்த விஷயத்தில் வேறுபட்ட பார்வையைக் கொண்டிருந்தனர். வழக்கமான சட்டங்களை குறியீடாக்குவதற்கான முயற்சிகளை அவர்கள் தொடர்ந்தனர், முக்கியமாக காண்டியன் சட்டம், ஆனால் அவர்கள் தங்கள் சட்டங்கள் மற்றும் பழக்கவழக்கங்கள் உட்பட தங்கள் நிறுவனங்களுக்கு மரியாதை செலுத்துவதை உறுதி செய்வதற்காக ஒரு வெறித்தனமான ஆர்வத்தால் இயக்கப்பட்டனர்.

The 19th century British experiment, of nurturing a narrow circle of elites committed to European customs, manners, habits, and prejudices, thus found a pivot in Sri Lanka, or Ceylon. இலங்கையில், பிரிட்டிஷ் அதிகாரிகள் தங்கள் ஆட்சிக்கு எதிராக அவ்வப்போது கிளர்ச்சியடைந்த போதிலும், அவர்களுக்கு பலனளிக்க விரும்பும் ஒரு உயரடுக்கைக் கண்டனர். By the time it gained independence in 1948, the country had gained a reputation as the most conservative colony in Asia.

இந்த பின்னணியில் தான் சட்டக் கல்லூரியின் வரலாறு மற்றும் பாதையை பட்டியலிட வேண்டும். 1874 ஆம் ஆண்டில், சட்ட கல்வி கவுன்சில் நிறுவப்பட்டபோது, ​​செழித்து வளரும் நடுத்தர வர்க்கம், சீர்திருத்தவாதி அவர்களின் கண்ணோட்டத்தில் தீவிரமாக இல்லாவிட்டால், நாட்டில் முளைத்தது.

As countless scholars, prominently Kumari Jayawardena, have noted, this middle-class was conservative and nationalist to varying degrees: some preferred to cooperate with the colonial administration, while others vied for reform. Almost all of them were content with their country falling within the orbit of British imperialism.

எல்லாவற்றிற்கும் மேலாக, இந்த நடுத்தர வர்க்கம் தங்கள் நிலையையும் க ti ரவத்தையும் பராமரிப்பதற்கான வழிகளை நாடியது. In the last quarter of the 19th century, the professions held a certain appeal for them. மருத்துவமும் சட்டமும் குறிப்பாக செல்வத்திற்கு உறுதியளிப்பதாகத் தோன்றியது, இல்லையென்றால் அந்தஸ்தும் இல்லை. As the sociologist Ralph Pieris would much later write:

“In Ceylon, specialisation was limited by the narrow range of career opportunities of an elitist kind, the lowest in terms of status being that of graduate teacher, the highest the prestigious Civil Service.”

Between the graduate teacher and the Civil Service, the Ceylonese had much to choose from, depending on their station in life. The middle-class, however, faced a paradox: they lacked the advantages of wealth the colonial elite had, yet were animated by the same aspirations as the latter. In the late 19th century, only medicine, and to a greater degree law, could square the circle and resolve this dilemma.

வக்கீல்கள் 20 ஆம் நூற்றாண்டில் ஒரு செல்வாக்குமிக்க குழுவை உருவாக்கினர். The Council of Legal Education, the sole body responsible for the admission and regulation of lawyers – Advocates and Proctors then, Attorneys-at-Law now – produced some of the most reformist, and also some of the most conservative, faces of colonial society.

Their intervention, in the context of the struggle for independence, cannot be ignored. When the first political party to call for complete independence from the British Empire, the Lanka Sama Samaja Party, was formed in 1935, it counted among its first batch, so to speak, a doctor and a lawyer – S. A. Wickramasinghe, and Colvin R. de Silva.

மற்றொரு உதாரணத்தை அளிக்க, 1911 சட்டமன்ற கவுன்சில் தேர்தலில் படித்த இலங்கோனிய இருக்கைக்கான போட்டியில் அதிகம் பேசப்பட்ட மற்றும் எழுதப்பட்டவை இந்தத் தொழிலில் இருந்து இரண்டு பிரதிநிதிகள் மீது முக்கியத்துவம் வாய்ந்தவை: சிங்கள கோவிகாமா உயரடுக்கின் விருப்பமான பொன்னம்பலம் ராமநாதன் மற்றும் டாக்டர் மார்கஸ் பெர்னாண்டோ ஆகியோரை பிரதிநிதித்துவப்படுத்துங்கள்காரவா முதலாளித்துவம்.

இன்று, நிச்சயமாக, விஷயங்கள் வியத்தகு முறையில் மாறிவிட்டன. Right after or before independence, Sri Lanka’s first Cabinet Minister for Education, Eddie Nugawela, made some remarks about the social composition among students at his school, Royal College.

Since Kannangara’s proposals, Nugawela remarked, “the Royal College is no more a school for the rich and privileged classes.” Observing that 317 of 519 parents worked as “peons, labourers, chauffeurs, and so on”, he concluded that the school had opened its gates to “the lower-middle class.”

It is transformations like these that have made institutions in Sri Lanka more representative, inclusive, and relevant, than they were at the heyday of colonialism. இந்த நிறுவனங்களை தங்களால் இயன்ற அளவிற்கு திறக்கும் போது தரநிலைகள், நெறிமுறைகள் மற்றும் வரையறைகளை பராமரிப்பதே இன்றைய சவால்.
இது நாம் நிறுத்தக்கூடிய ஒன்றல்ல;இது நாம் ஏற்றுக்கொள்ள வேண்டிய ஒன்று.
This book, in its own humble way, attempts to grapple with these questions and issues. இது இந்த விஷயத்தில் இறுதி வார்த்தையாக அல்ல, மாறாக பல முயற்சிகளைத் பின்பற்ற வேண்டும்.

The truth is that the Sri Lanka Law College is an institution that has withstood the test of time. It is currently going through a major bout of reform. One can only hope that as it forges ahead, it remains mindful of its essential task – ensuring a legal profession that is closer to, representative of, inclusive of, and accountable to its people.

எங்கள் அரசியல்வாதிகள் மற்றும் தேர்ந்தெடுக்கப்பட்ட அதிகாரிகளிடமிருந்து பொறுப்புக்கூறலைக் கோருகிறோம். புத்தகத்தின் ஆசிரியராக, எங்கள் தொழில்கள் மற்றும் நிபுணர்களுடன் நாம் ஏன் இதைச் செய்யக்கூடாது என்று என்னால் கற்பனை செய்து பார்க்க முடியாது.

Institutions have a large role to play in this. பெரும்பாலும், இலங்கையில் உள்ள நிறுவனங்கள் பிராந்தியமாக இருக்கின்றன, சில நேரங்களில் பகுத்தறிவற்றவை. They tend to be averse to collaboration and cooperation, they tend to claim credit for themselves. Sri Lanka is currently at a crossroads in its modern history. If it is to progress, it must abandon this attitude.
Ultimately, it is that hope which resides in this book, and, in its own special way, the future of the Sri Lanka Law College.

Uditha Devapriya is the author of “Uplifting Legal Education in Sri Lanka: 150 Years of Law College”, a study of the Sri Lanka Law College launched on October 18. புத்தகம் சட்டக் கல்லூரியில் கிடைக்கிறது. புத்தகத்திற்கான ஆராய்ச்சி மற்றும் தொகுப்பு ஆசிய-பசிபிக் கவனம் செலுத்திய வெளியுறவுக் கொள்கை சிந்தனைக் குழுவான ஃபேக்டமால் செய்யப்பட்டது, அங்கு உதிதா தற்போது தலைமை சர்வதேச உறவுகள் ஆய்வாளராக பணியாற்றுகிறார். மின்னஞ்சல்: udakdev1@gmail.com
